objtitle.title: *Naomi Entreating Ruth and Orpah to Return to the Land of Moab*

objinfo.printdate: 1795The characteristics of the color printing indicate that this impression is the second one printed in 1795. The first impression in this printing is *Naomi Entreating Ruth and Orpah to Return to the Land of Moab* in the Victoria and Albert Museum (Butlin 299).
objinfo.objsize: 37.5 x 49.0 cm.The design has been trimmed on all four margins, probably long after it left Blake's hands.
objinfo.medium: planographic color printing with water color and pen and ink additions to the impressionThe varnish on the work has darkened with age. This varnish was probably added long after the work left Blake's hands.

provenance.name: Fitzwilliam Museum
provenance.note: Inherited by Blake's wife Catherine upon his death in 1827; acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; possibly the dealer Joseph Hogarth in the first half of the nineteenth century; unrecorded collector or collectors; acquired by Joseph Whitwell Pease (1828-1903) by the second half of the nineteenth century; Miss S. H. Pease by inheritance in 1903; her executor, Lord Wardington, no later than 1938; sold Christie's, 2 Dec. 1938, lot 58 (£52.10s. to Geoffrey Keynes); by bequest to the Keynes Family Trust upon Geoffrey Keynes' death in 1982, on deposit at the Fitzwilliam Museum; by allocation to Quentin Keynes (1921-2003); accepted by the British government in lieu of inheritance tax on the estate of Quentin Keynes and allocated to the Fitzwilliam Museum in 2005.

repository.addressline: URL, Paintings, Drawings and Prints: http://www.fitmuseum.cam.ac.uk/dept/pdp

desc.objtitle: Naomi Entreating Ruth and Orpah to Return to the Land of Moab, Object 1 (Butlin 300)

objnote.p: "Naomi Entreating Ruth and Orpah to Return to the Land of Moab" illustrates Ruth 1:11-17. Ruth clings to her mother-in-law on the left, while Orpah, also a widow of one of Naomi's sons, departs on the right in sorrow to return to her own land of Moab. Ruth will follow Naomi to Bethlehem.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Naomi stands on the left side of the design with her arms open, receiving Ruth’s embrace. Naomi's hands are prominent, with palms out and fingers spread. Ruth, hunching over and looking down, embraces Naomi. On the right, Orpah walks away from the two women, bent over with her right hand on or behind her head while looking down. The scene is set on grassy or mossy earth before a line of hills or mountains or a grove of trees or bushes, with a narrow band of sky above.

component.illusobjdesc: Naomi, an old woman, is gowned and stands with her arms extended outward from her body at 45 degrees. With open palms and spread fingers, she receives Ruth's embrace. Naomi faces forward, and her left leg steps before her right leg, making her left foot prominent. A veil or scarf covers her hair and falls over her right shoulder. She faces the viewer though she looks somewhat to her left with her eyes lowered. Her mouth may be slightly open. Lines on her face suggest old-age and perhaps worry or grief.

Ruth embraces Naomi on the left. Ruth's right arm is wrapped behind Naomi, making only her right fingers discernible on Naomi’s right hip. Ruth bends forward, toward Naomi, and looks down. Ruth's left arm is extended at 45 degrees to embrace Naomi's right thigh. Ruth is gowned, with a belt at her waist and with her left foot prominent at the hem. She has long hair that cascades over her back. Her left leg is bent at her prominent knee.

Hunched over and facing right and down, Orpah turns away from Naomi and Ruth. She walks toward the right margin with her right leg bent at the knee and extended behind her, her right foot on tiptoe. Her right arm is bent upwards towards her face, with her right hand behind (and possibly touching) her face. She may be crying. She has long curly hair, perhaps partly pulled up into a bun, and her mouth may be slightly open. She is gowned, with the swirling hem indicating her movement.
The foreground of the design appears to be a grassy or mossy strip of earth, possibly with shadows extending from the figures toward the right.
The midground appears to be blocked by a dark line of hills or mountains or a grove of trees or bushes. A narrow band of sky is visible at the top of the design.
